newsitem.title: USA: Strikes to lower Big Three second-quarter profits.
newsitem.headline: Strikes to lower Big Three second-quarter profits.

text.p: Battered by labour strikes, higher incentives and slowing sales, combined net profits for the Big Three automakers are expected to fall an estimated 11 percent from a year ago, analysts said.
Strikes alone will slice nearly $1 billion from the net earnings of General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp.
The Big Three as a group are expected to report combined earnings of about $4.5 billion for the April-June period, according to analysts. A year ago, they reported earnings of $5.04 billion.
Ford Motor Co. is forecast to post the best returns for the quarter, which would allow it to out-earn archrival GM for the first time in more than 9 years.
Most analysts said they expect Ford to earn between $2.2 billion and $2.3 billion. However, Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst Nicholas Lobaccaro has estimated the company will earn $2.5 billion.

The First Call Corp., which monitors Wall Street earnings projections, said its consensus estimate for Ford's 1997 second period is $1.82 a share. A year ago, Ford earned $1.90 billion, or $1.56 a share.
The U.S. No. 2 automaker, which will report results July 16, the same day as GM, is on a cost-cutting roll and enjoying some of the best labour relations in the industry.
Ford has also benefited from the hugely profitable Expedition. The full-size sport/utility vehicle carries gross profits of $11,000 for each unit.

Chrysler will be the first to report when it releases results on Friday. It is expected to post net earnings of $512 million, about half of the $1.04 billion it earned in the 1996 second quarter, according to David Healy, an analyst with Burnham Securities Inc.

Healy estimates the No. 3 automaker will earn $512 million, or 75 cents a share, down from $1.38 a year ago, but slightly higher than the 68 cents per share analysts' consensus compiled by First Call.

A 30-day strike by United Auto Workers union members at a Detroit-area engine plant this spring forced Chrysler to shut down much of its light-truck output. Chrysler lost out on production of 94,000 vehicles, worth $450 million, or 65 cents a share in lost profits.

But Healy said even without the strike, Chrysler would probably not have matched last year's returns. One reason is bigger sales incentives. Healy estimates they climbed to an average of $1,000 as Chrysler sought to spur minivan and car sales. Last year, Chrysler said its average second period U.S. retail incentive was $625.
"Probably the higher incentives and maybe a little less favourable mix than last year would have brought them below second-quarter earnings without the strikes," said Healy.
GM has said two strikes will reduce its second-quarter profits by $490 million or 67 cents a share.
Healy predicts that will bring GM's second-quarter earnings to $1.64 billion. On a per-share basis, the estimate works out to $2.16, slightly above the First Call consensus of $2.15.
